Families:

Yesterday, the Office of Public Instruction released the much-anticipated guidance for returning to school in the fall. As Union Gap School District plans for different school scenarios required by this guidance, be assured that we are committed to doing whatever it takes to protect our community’s health and ensure that every child can achieve to their highest level. We anticipate sharing our reopening guide with you no later than the week of July 20. Planning efforts will be ongoing throughout the summer and our strategies may be adjusted and refined as we head into the school year. Clear and transparent decision-making is a priority for us, and we will provide regular updates to make sure you have the latest information.

If you are interested in reading the state's guidelines, you can find them here:

https://www.k12.wa.us/sites/default/files/public/workgroups/Reopening%20Washington%20Schools%202020%20Planning%20Guide.pdf

Stay safe. Please heed health officials' guidance in our county. We want to see our students.

Lisa Gredvig
Superintendent

post_text: Did You Know: Good attendance in the early grades can build a child’s perseverance to succeed throughout all of their years at school. For a child of any age, any absence creates lost opportunities in that student’s learning, growth, and future success. Help make a difference during September’s School Attendance Awareness Month … and throughout the rest of this school year!

post_text: Good attendance during the first month of school can establish a positive pattern for your child’s classroom attendance throughout the rest of the school year. Research shows that 9 out of 10 students who miss 5 days during September become chronically absent and that their rate of missed school days increases throughout the school year. Help make a difference during September’s School Attendance Awareness Month!

post_text: Chronic absenteeism at school can come from 3 main causes: (1) Misconceptions among adults about the importance of regular school attendance, (2) a student's academic- or social-based aversion to showing up for class, or (3) health challenges, such as asthma, oral health issues, and mental health or trauma (including anxiety or depression). Any reason for a student being chronically absent can impede a child's equal opportunities to learn and succeed. Help make a difference during September’s School Attendance Awareness Month!

post_text: It’s highly important to establish a strong habit of good class attendance as the new school year begins. Chronic absenteeism is defined as missing 10% of the school year – an average of just 2 days per month. This can translate into young children not properly mastering reading or math, and can increase the chances of students dropping out during high school. Don’t let the absences add up! Help make a difference during September’s School Attendance Awareness Month!
